Title:
Conflict of arbitrary sequence-based species concepts with
phylogenetic evidence: a case study in green algae
Keywords:
CBCAnalyzer, Chlorophyceae, DNA barcode, ITS, molecular
synapomorphy, secondary structure
Abstract:
The ITS2 rDNA is commonly used in systematic studies due
to its ease of amplification and high levels of intrageneric variation.
Previously, an approach to delimiting species based on the presence of
compensatory base changes (CBCs) has been proposed. The present study
focuses on a group of closely related strains of green algae and shows a
case of autapomorphic CBCs, which results in a conflict of the CBC
approach with phylogenetic evidence obtained from the same data set. In
addition, we evaluated another arbitrary species-delimitation criterion,
the barcoding gap, in the clade of interest.
